**Transcript**:
Compared to the whitewater streams that tumble
down mountainsides, the meandering rivers of the plains may seem tame and lazy. But
mountain streams are corralled by the steep-walled valleys they carve – their courses are literally
set in stone. Out on the open plains, those stony walls give way to soft soil, allowing
rivers much more freedom to shift their banks and set their own ever-changing courses to
the sea: courses that almost never run straight. At least not for long, because all it takes
to turn a straight stretch of river into a bendy one is a little disturbance and a lot
of time  – and in nature, there’s plenty of both.
      Say, for example, that a muskrat  burrows
herself a den in one bank of a stream. Her tunnels make for a cozy home,  but they also
weaken the bank, which eventually begins to crumble and slump into the stream. Water rushes into the newly-formed hollow,
sweeping away loose dirt and making the hollow even hollower, which lets the water rush a
little faster and sweep away a little more dirt from the bank...and so on, and so on
. As more of the stream’s flow is diverted
into the deepening hole on one bank and away from the other side of the channel, the flow
there weakens and slows. And since slow-moving water can’t carry the sand-sized particles
that fast-moving water can, that dirt drops to the bottom and builds up to make the water
there shallower and slower, and then keeps accumulating until the edge of the stream
becomes new land on the inside bank.        
Meanwhile, the fast-moving water near the outside bank sweeps out of the curve with
enough momentum to carry it across the channel and slam it into the other side, where it
starts to carve another curve . And then another, and then another, and then another. The wider
the stream, the longer it takes the slingshotting current to reach the other side, and the greater
the downstream distance to the next curve. In fact, measurements of meandering streams
all over the world reveal a strikingly regular pattern : the length of one S-shaped meander
tends to be about six times the width of the channel . So little tiny meandering streams
tend to look just like miniature versions of their bigger relatives.
     As long as nothing gets in the way of a river’s
meandering , its curves will continue to grow curvier and curvier until they loop around
and bumble into themselves. When that happens, the river follows the straighter path downhill,
leaving behind a crescent-shaped remnant called an oxbow lake. Or a billabong. Or a lago en
herradura. Or a bras mort ...     
We have lots of names for these lakes, since they can occur pretty much anywhere liquid
flows – which brings up an interesting question:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 7

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever been gazing at a starry sky when suddenly 
a bright dot glided into view? If it wasn't blinking, then you've had
the distinct pleasure of seeing one of mankind's greatest 
collaborative feats with your own eyes: The International Space Station. Roughly the size of six-bedroom house,
and weighing more than 320 cars, the International Space Station 
is so large that no single rocket could have 
lifted it into orbit. Instead, it was assembled piece by piece while hurtling through space
at 28,000 kilometers per hour, lapping the Earth once every 90 minutes. It all started when sixteen nations signed the Space Station 
Intergovernmental Agreement, laying out each partner's 
expected contributions to the ISS, from modules and maintenance
to sharing information and finances. At an estimated 100 billion U.S. dollars, the Space Station would be
the most expensive object ever built. The whole world watched as a Russian rocket launched 
the first module of the ISS into the sky. Zarya, meaning sunrise, 
was equipped with two solar panels and a propulsion system 
that had the important task of keeping the young station 
from crashing into the Earth by staying a safe 400 kilometers away. The U.S. Space Shuttle Endeavour
followed two weeks later carrying Unity, a node module to which
other modules could be connected, and an international 
six-person assembly crew. Then came Zvezda, which brought
communications and living accommodations. Ever since the International 
Space Station's first tenants arrived, it's been continually occupied with more than 200 visitors spending 
an average of six months on board. Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti 
holds the record for the longest single space flight
by a woman at 199 days on the ISS. 2001 saw the arrival of Destiny,
the first of four research modules, where astronauts spend
approximately 36 hours a week conducting extraordinary experiments
in microgravity. Their schedules are packed with exercise, two hours a day to fend off 
muscle atrophy, station maintenance and repair, and connecting with family 
or awe-inspired minds around the world. But they still find time for fun,
with regular movie nights and even shooting 
the first music video in space. Destiny also controls the seven-jointed
robotic Canadarm2. Capable of moving 
more than 100,000 kilograms, it's perfect for unloading 
new arrivals from shuttles. 2001 was a busy year for the Space Station
with the addition of Quest, the main airlock for strolls outside, and Pirs, a pier for Russian 
spacecrafts to dock including the ever-ready 
emergency escape vehicle, Soyuz. Then, on February 1st, 2003, after delivering 
research modules to the ISS, the space shuttle
Columbia exploded during reentry tragically killing 
the seven-member crew on board. After a four-year hiatus, work quickly
picked up pace with the addition of more hubs, 
airlocks, docks, and an observation cupola for stunning
360-degree views of our world and beyond. Other critical components included 
platforms and trusses to support radiators that direct all the heat generated
by the station's electronics into space and solar panels that are efficient enough
to power 55 homes. It took ten years and over 30 missions, but finally, the International 
Space Station was complete, coinciding with the U.S. Space 
Shuttle Program's retirement. The Space Station continues to serve
as an incredible model for international collaboration. This year, two people 
began a one-year stay on the ISS, allowing scientists to study the long-term
physical and psychological effects of being in space, which would prove useful for increasingly
ambitious space travel, like trips to Mars. Over its lifetime, we've learned 
an immense amount scientifically, but also about 
our capacity to work together and accomplish truly remarkable acts.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long does it take the International Space Station to orbit the earth?
Options: A. 1.5 hours, B. 2 hours, C. 6 hours, D. 24 hours
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate size of the International Space Station? Options: A. A small car, B. A six-bedroom house, C. A large skyscraper, D. A football stadium Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the process of assembling the International Space Station. Options: A. It was built on Earth and launched into space as a single unit., B. It was assembled piece by piece while in orbit around the Earth., C. It was constructed on the Moon and then transported to Earth's orbit., D. It was built by a single nation without any international collaboration. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were an engineer designing a new module for the International Space Station, what would be a crucial consideration to ensure the module's safe operation? Options: A. The module's color scheme, B. The module's compatibility with existing ISS systems, C. The module's size and weight, D. The module's country of origin Correct Option: B
Question 4: Analyze the role of the Zarya module in the early stages of the International Space Station's development. Options: A. Zarya provided living accommodations for the first ISS crew., B. Zarya served as a node module for connecting other modules., C. Zarya was equipped with solar panels and a propulsion system to maintain the ISS's orbit., D. Zarya was the first research module for conducting scientific experiments. Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do astronauts on the International Space Station spend most of their time? Options: A. Conducting spacewalks and maintaining the station's exterior, B. Engaging in recreational activities like movie nights and music videos, C. Exercising, conducting scientific experiments, and performing station maintenance, D. Sleeping and relaxing due to the microgravity environment Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the primary function of the Canadarm2 robotic arm on the International Space Station? Options: A. To conduct scientific experiments in microgravity, B. To unload new arrivals from shuttles and move heavy objects, C. To provide a means of emergency escape for the ISS crew, D. To maintain the station's solar panels and radiators Correct Option: B
Question 7: Synthesize the benefits of the International Space Station's modular design and international collaboration. Options: A. The ISS's modular design and international collaboration have hindered its development and operation., B. The ISS's modular design has allowed for easier maintenance, while international collaboration has facilitated knowledge sharing and cost savings., C. The ISS's modular design has increased its construction costs, but international collaboration has improved its scientific output., D. The ISS's modular design and international collaboration have had no significant impact on its success. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Evaluate the significance of the International Space Station as a model for international collaboration. Options: A. The ISS is a minor example of international cooperation with limited scientific and technological benefits., B. The ISS is a significant achievement in international collaboration, demonstrating the potential for nations to work together on complex projects., C. The ISS is a failure of international collaboration, plagued by delays, cost overruns, and conflicting national interests., D. The ISS is an isolated incident of international cooperation, with no broader implications for future collaborations. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is one of the long-term benefits of the International Space Station's continued operation? Options: A. Providing a permanent human settlement on the Moon, B. Facilitating the development of a new generation of space shuttles, C. Enabling scientists to study the long-term effects of space travel on the human body, D. Supporting the establishment of a human settlement on Mars Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated total cost of the International Space Station's construction and operation? Options: A. $10 billion, B. $50 billion, C. $100 billion, D. $500 billion Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the time it takes for the International Space Station to orbit the Earth. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 4 discusses the role of the Zarya module, which includes maintaining the ISS's orbit.

Although not a perfect match, I would recommend Question 4 as the most similar generated MCQ, as it indirectly relates to the ISS's orbit.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Please note that this is not an exact match, and a more accurate generated MCQ would be needed to perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever been gazing at a starry sky when suddenly 
a bright dot glided into view? If it wasn't blinking, then you've had
the distinct pleasure of seeing one of mankind's greatest 
collaborative feats with your own eyes: The International Space Station. Roughly the size of six-bedroom house,
and weighing more than 320 cars, the International Space Station 
is so large that no single rocket could have 
lifted it into orbit. Instead, it was assembled piece by piece while hurtling through space
at 28,000 kilometers per hour, lapping the Earth once every 90 minutes. It all started when sixteen nations signed the Space Station 
Intergovernmental Agreement, laying out each partner's 
expected contributions to the ISS, from modules and maintenance
to sharing information and finances. At an estimated 100 billion U.S. dollars, the Space Station would be
the most expensive object ever built. The whole world watched as a Russian rocket launched 
the first module of the ISS into the sky. Zarya, meaning sunrise, 
was equipped with two solar panels and a propulsion system 
that had the important task of keeping the young station 
from crashing into the Earth by staying a safe 400 kilometers away. The U.S. Space Shuttle Endeavour
followed two weeks later carrying Unity, a node module to which
other modules could be connected, and an international 
six-person assembly crew. Then came Zvezda, which brought
communications and living accommodations. Ever since the International 
Space Station's first tenants arrived, it's been continually occupied with more than 200 visitors spending 
an average of six months on board. Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti 
holds the record for the longest single space flight
by a woman at 199 days on the ISS. 2001 saw the arrival of Destiny,
the first of four research modules, where astronauts spend
approximately 36 hours a week conducting extraordinary experiments
in microgravity. Their schedules are packed with exercise, two hours a day to fend off 
muscle atrophy, station maintenance and repair, and connecting with family 
or awe-inspired minds around the world. But they still find time for fun,
with regular movie nights and even shooting 
the first music video in space. Destiny also controls the seven-jointed
robotic Canadarm2. Capable of moving 
more than 100,000 kilograms, it's perfect for unloading 
new arrivals from shuttles. 2001 was a busy year for the Space Station
with the addition of Quest, the main airlock for strolls outside, and Pirs, a pier for Russian 
spacecrafts to dock including the ever-ready 
emergency escape vehicle, Soyuz. Then, on February 1st, 2003, after delivering 
research modules to the ISS, the space shuttle
Columbia exploded during reentry tragically killing 
the seven-member crew on board. After a four-year hiatus, work quickly
picked up pace with the addition of more hubs, 
airlocks, docks, and an observation cupola for stunning
360-degree views of our world and beyond. Other critical components included 
platforms and trusses to support radiators that direct all the heat generated
by the station's electronics into space and solar panels that are efficient enough
to power 55 homes. It took ten years and over 30 missions, but finally, the International 
Space Station was complete, coinciding with the U.S. Space 
Shuttle Program's retirement. The Space Station continues to serve
as an incredible model for international collaboration. This year, two people 
began a one-year stay on the ISS, allowing scientists to study the long-term
physical and psychological effects of being in space, which would prove useful for increasingly
ambitious space travel, like trips to Mars. Over its lifetime, we've learned 
an immense amount scientifically, but also about 
our capacity to work together and accomplish truly remarkable acts.

Correct Option: D

to power 55 homes. It took ten years and over 30 missions, but finally, the International 
Space Station was complete, coinciding with the U.S. Space 
Shuttle Program's retirement. The Space Station continues to serve
as an incredible model for international collaboration. This year, two people 
began a one-year stay on the ISS, allowing scientists to study the long-term
physical and psychological effects of being in space, which would prove useful for increasingly
ambitious space travel, like trips to Mars. Over its lifetime, we've learned 
an immense amount scientifically, but also about 
our capacity to work together and accomplish truly remarkable acts.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how big is the International Space Station?
Options: A. Roughly the size of a 3-bedroom house, B. Roughly the size of a 5-bedroom house, C. Roughly the size of a 4-bedroom house, D. Roughly the size of a 6-bedroom house
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate size of the International Space Station? Options: A. A small car, B. A six-bedroom house, C. A large skyscraper, D. A football stadium Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the process of assembling the International Space Station. Options: A. It was built on Earth and launched into space as a single unit., B. It was assembled piece by piece while in orbit around the Earth., C. It was constructed on the Moon and then transported to Earth's orbit., D. It was built by a single nation without any international collaboration. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were an engineer designing a new module for the International Space Station, what would be a crucial consideration to ensure the module's safe operation? Options: A. The module's color scheme, B. The module's compatibility with existing ISS systems, C. The module's size and weight, D. The module's country of origin Correct Option: B
Question 4: Analyze the role of the Zarya module in the early stages of the International Space Station's development. Options: A. Zarya provided living accommodations for the first ISS crew., B. Zarya served as a node module for connecting other modules., C. Zarya was equipped with solar panels and a propulsion system to maintain the ISS's orbit., D. Zarya was the first research module for conducting scientific experiments. Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do astronauts on the International Space Station spend most of their time? Options: A. Conducting spacewalks and maintaining the station's exterior, B. Engaging in recreational activities like movie nights and music videos, C. Exercising, conducting scientific experiments, and performing station maintenance, D. Sleeping and relaxing due to the microgravity environment Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the primary function of the Canadarm2 robotic arm on the International Space Station? Options: A. To conduct scientific experiments in microgravity, B. To unload new arrivals from shuttles and move heavy objects, C. To provide a means of emergency escape for the ISS crew, D. To maintain the station's solar panels and radiators Correct Option: B
Question 7: Synthesize the benefits of the International Space Station's modular design and international collaboration. Options: A. The ISS's modular design and international collaboration have hindered its development and operation., B. The ISS's modular design has allowed for easier maintenance, while international collaboration has facilitated knowledge sharing and cost savings., C. The ISS's modular design has increased its construction costs, but international collaboration has improved its scientific output., D. The ISS's modular design and international collaboration have had no significant impact on its success. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Evaluate the significance of the International Space Station as a model for international collaboration. Options: A. The ISS is a minor example of international cooperation with limited scientific and technological benefits., B. The ISS is a significant achievement in international collaboration, demonstrating the potential for nations to work together on complex projects., C. The ISS is a failure of international collaboration, plagued by delays, cost overruns, and conflicting national interests., D. The ISS is an isolated incident of international cooperation, with no broader implications for future collaborations. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is one of the long-term benefits of the International Space Station's continued operation? Options: A. Providing a permanent human settlement on the Moon, B. Facilitating the development of a new generation of space shuttles, C. Enabling scientists to study the long-term effects of space travel on the human body, D. Supporting the establishment of a human settlement on Mars Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated total cost of the International Space Station's construction and operation? Options: A. $10 billion, B. $50 billion, C. $100 billion, D. $500 billion Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever been gazing at a starry sky when suddenly 
a bright dot glided into view? If it wasn't blinking, then you've had
the distinct pleasure of seeing one of mankind's greatest 
collaborative feats with your own eyes: The International Space Station. Roughly the size of six-bedroom house,
and weighing more than 320 cars, the International Space Station 
is so large that no single rocket could have 
lifted it into orbit. Instead, it was assembled piece by piece while hurtling through space
at 28,000 kilometers per hour, lapping the Earth once every 90 minutes. It all started when sixteen nations signed the Space Station 
Intergovernmental Agreement, laying out each partner's 
expected contributions to the ISS, from modules and maintenance
to sharing information and finances. At an estimated 100 billion U.S. dollars, the Space Station would be
the most expensive object ever built. The whole world watched as a Russian rocket launched 
the first module of the ISS into the sky. Zarya, meaning sunrise, 
was equipped with two solar panels and a propulsion system 
that had the important task of keeping the young station 
from crashing into the Earth by staying a safe 400 kilometers away. The U.S. Space Shuttle Endeavour
followed two weeks later carrying Unity, a node module to which
other modules could be connected, and an international 
six-person assembly crew. Then came Zvezda, which brought
communications and living accommodations. Ever since the International 
Space Station's first tenants arrived, it's been continually occupied with more than 200 visitors spending 
an average of six months on board. Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti 
holds the record for the longest single space flight
by a woman at 199 days on the ISS. 2001 saw the arrival of Destiny,
the first of four research modules, where astronauts spend
approximately 36 hours a week conducting extraordinary experiments
in microgravity. Their schedules are packed with exercise, two hours a day to fend off 
muscle atrophy, station maintenance and repair, and connecting with family 
or awe-inspired minds around the world. But they still find time for fun,
with regular movie nights and even shooting 
the first music video in space. Destiny also controls the seven-jointed
robotic Canadarm2. Capable of moving 
more than 100,000 kilograms, it's perfect for unloading 
new arrivals from shuttles. 2001 was a busy year for the Space Station
with the addition of Quest, the main airlock for strolls outside, and Pirs, a pier for Russian 
spacecrafts to dock including the ever-ready 
emergency escape vehicle, Soyuz. Then, on February 1st, 2003, after delivering 
research modules to the ISS, the space shuttle
Columbia exploded during reentry tragically killing 
the seven-member crew on board. After a four-year hiatus, work quickly
picked up pace with the addition of more hubs, 
airlocks, docks, and an observation cupola for stunning
360-degree views of our world and beyond. Other critical components included 
platforms and trusses to support radiators that direct all the heat generated
by the station's electronics into space and solar panels that are efficient enough
to power 55 homes. It took ten years and over 30 missions, but finally, the International 
Space Station was complete, coinciding with the U.S. Space 
Shuttle Program's retirement. The Space Station continues to serve
as an incredible model for international collaboration. This year, two people 
began a one-year stay on the ISS, allowing scientists to study the long-term
physical and psychological effects of being in space, which would prove useful for increasingly
ambitious space travel, like trips to Mars. Over its lifetime, we've learned 
an immense amount scientifically, but also about 
our capacity to work together and accomplish truly remarkable acts.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Zarya was the first module of the ISS to be launched into space — what does the word "Zarya" mean?
Options: A. Sunset, B. Sunrise, C. Star, D. Sky
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
An estimated 20 million cases of blindness
worldwide are caused by cataracts, a curable condition affecting the lens
that focuses images onto the eye's retina. A cataract occurs when proteins 
in the lens lose their normal arrangement, clumping together in a way that causes
discoloration or clouding, and eventually blocks most vision. Cataracts can be caused by eye injury, certain medications, ultraviolet radiation, diabetes, smoking, or some genetic disorders. But the most common cause is aging. In the United States, more than 50%
of people over the age of 80 develop them. Cataracts were treated 
over 2,500 years ago in India, though similar procedures 
may have existed even earlier in Ancient Egypt and Babylon. The most common procedure,
called couching, involved pressing 
a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen and push 
the clouded lens out of the way. Although this could increase 
the amount of light entering the eye, the lack of a lens would leave 
the patient's vision out of focus. Despite its low success rate,
and high risk of infection or injury, couching is still performed 
in some parts of the world. Later procedures would also focus
on removing the cloudy lens, for example, by making an opening
in the cornea to pull out the lens along with the membrane capsule 
surrounding it. While the invention of eyeglasses
allowed for some restoration of focus, they had to be extremely thick to help. Furthermore, such techniques
still caused complications, like damaging the retina, or leaving the eye 
with uncomfortable stitches. But in the 20th century, 
something unexpected happened. Eye surgeon Sir Harold Ridley was treating
World War II casualties when he noticed that acrylic plastic from
a shattered aircraft cockpit had become lodged in a pilot's eyes
without triggering an adverse reaction. This led him to propose surgically
implanting artificial lenses into the eye to replace cataracts. And despite initial resistance, the method became standard practice
by the 1980s. Since Ridley's discovery, the intraocular lens 
has undergone several improvements. Modern lenses can fit 
into the membrane capsule that the cataract is extracted from, leaving more of 
the eye's natural anatomy intact. And the ability to fine-tune 
the lens curvature allows the surgery to restore 
a patient's normal vision without the need for glasses. Of course, surgical techniques 
have also progressed. Microscopic procedures use 
small instruments or lasers to make precise incisions of one 
or two millimeters in the cornea, while an ultrasound probe breaks up
and removes the cataracted lens with minimal trauma to the eye. Low-tech versions of this operation have
made the surgery quick and inexpensive, helping it spread 
across the developing world. Places like Aravind Eye Hospital in India have pioneered high-volume, 
low-cost cataract surgery for as little as six dollars. Why then, with all these advances, are there still so many 
blind people in the world? The main issue is access to health care, with poor infrastructure 
and a shortage of doctors being a major barrier in many regions. But this is not the only problem. In many rural areas with poor education, blindness is often accepted 
as an inevitable part of aging, for which someone 
might not think to seek treatment. This is why information is crucial. Increased community awareness programs
and the spread of mobile phones mean that many of those who might have remained blind for
the rest of their lives due to cataracts are now reachable. And for them, 
a brighter future is in sight.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many people in the world are estimated to be blind from cataracts?
Options: A. 20,000, B. 80,000, C. 20,000,000, D. 39,000,000
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of cases of blindness worldwide caused by cataracts? Options: A. 10 million, B. 20 million, C. 30 million, D. 40 million Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary cause of cataracts, according to the transcript? Options: A. Eye injury, B. Certain medications, C. Aging, D. Diabetes Correct Option: C
Question 3: Describe the ancient procedure called "couching" used to treat cataracts. What was its major limitation? Options: A. It involved removing the cloudy lens, but had a high risk of infection., B. It involved pressing a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen the clouded lens, but left the patient's vision out of focus., C. It involved making an opening in the cornea to pull out the lens, but caused complications like damaging the retina., D. It involved surgically implanting artificial lenses into the eye, but was not widely accepted. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What unexpected event led to the development of surgically implanting artificial lenses into the eye to replace cataracts? Options: A. The invention of eyeglasses, B. The observation of acrylic plastic from a shattered aircraft cockpit in a pilot's eyes, C. The discovery of a new medication for cataracts, D. The development of microscopic procedures Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main advantage of modern intraocular lenses compared to earlier versions? Options: A. They are less expensive, B. They can be implanted without surgery, C. They can fit into the membrane capsule, leaving more of the eye's natural anatomy intact, D. They require thicker eyeglasses for focus restoration Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the primary barrier to accessing cataract surgery in many regions? Options: A. Lack of education about cataracts, B. Poor infrastructure and a shortage of doctors, C. High cost of the surgery, D. Limited availability of intraocular lenses Correct Option: B
Question 7: How has the spread of mobile phones impacted access to cataract surgery? Options: A. It has increased the cost of the surgery, B. It has made it easier for people to seek treatment, C. It has reduced the availability of intraocular lenses, D. It has had no impact on access to cataract surgery Correct Option: B
Question 8: If a 75-year-old patient is diagnosed with cataracts, what would be the most suitable treatment option? Options: A. Couching, B. Eyeglasses, C. Surgically implanting an intraocular lens, D. Medication Correct Option: C
Question 9: Compare the outcomes of cataract surgery using microscopic procedures versus earlier techniques. What are the main differences? Options: A. Microscopic procedures have a higher risk of infection and require thicker eyeglasses., B. Microscopic procedures have a lower success rate and cause more trauma to the eye., C. Microscopic procedures have a higher success rate, cause minimal trauma to the eye, and do not require eyeglasses., D. Microscopic procedures have the same outcomes as earlier techniques. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Evaluate the impact of community awareness programs on reducing the number of people blind due to cataracts. What is the likely outcome of such programs? Options: A. They will have no impact on reducing blindness due to cataracts., B. They will increase the number of people seeking treatment, but not reduce blindness., C. They will reduce the number of people blind due to cataracts by increasing awareness and access to treatment., D. They will only be effective in urban areas. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Index: 1

Reasoning: 
- Both the ground truth MCQ and Question 1 ask about the estimated number of people blind due to cataracts.
- The options in both questions are numerical values, with the correct option being 20 million in both cases.
- The question content and intent are identical, with the only difference being the wording of the question. 

Therefore, Question 1 is the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

by the 1980s. Since Ridley's discovery, the intraocular lens 
has undergone several improvements. Modern lenses can fit 
into the membrane capsule that the cataract is extracted from, leaving more of 
the eye's natural anatomy intact. And the ability to fine-tune 
the lens curvature allows the surgery to restore

have also progressed. Microscopic procedures use

and removes the cataracted lens with minimal trauma to the eye. Low-tech versions of this operation have

might not think to seek treatment. This is why information is crucial. Increased community awareness programs
and the spread of mobile phones mean that many of those who might have remained blind for
the rest of their lives due to cataracts are now reachable. And for them, 
a brighter future is in sight.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cataracts affect the _____ of the eye.
Options: A. Cornea, B. Lens, C. Retina, D. Nerve
Correct Option: B

Question 2: What is the primary cause of cataracts, according to the transcript? Options: A. Eye injury, B. Certain medications, C. Aging, D. Diabetes Correct Option: C
Question 3: Describe the ancient procedure called "couching" used to treat cataracts. What was its major limitation? Options: A. It involved removing the cloudy lens, but had a high risk of infection., B. It involved pressing a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen the clouded lens, but left the patient's vision out of focus., C. It involved making an opening in the cornea to pull out the lens, but caused complications like damaging the retina., D. Question 6: What is the primary barrier to accessing cataract surgery in many regions? Options: A. Lack of education about cataracts, B. Poor infrastructure and a shortage of doctors, C. High cost of the surgery, D. Limited availability of intraocular lenses Correct Option: B
Question 7: How has the spread of mobile phones impacted access to cataract surgery? Options: A. It has increased the cost of the surgery, B. It has made it easier for people to seek treatment, C. It has reduced the availability of intraocular lenses, D. It has had no impact on access to cataract surgery Correct Option: B

Question 9: Compare the outcomes of cataract surgery using microscopic procedures versus earlier techniques. What are the main differences? Options: A. Microscopic procedures have a higher risk of infection and require thicker eyeglasses., B. Microscopic procedures have a lower success rate and cause more trauma to the eye., C. Microscopic procedures have a higher success rate, cause minimal trauma to the eye, and do not require eyeglasses., D. Microscopic procedures have the same outcomes as earlier techniques. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
An estimated 20 million cases of blindness
worldwide are caused by cataracts, a curable condition affecting the lens
that focuses images onto the eye's retina. A cataract occurs when proteins 
in the lens lose their normal arrangement, clumping together in a way that causes
discoloration or clouding, and eventually blocks most vision. Cataracts can be caused by eye injury, certain medications, ultraviolet radiation, diabetes, smoking, or some genetic disorders. But the most common cause is aging. In the United States, more than 50%
of people over the age of 80 develop them. Cataracts were treated 
over 2,500 years ago in India, though similar procedures 
may have existed even earlier in Ancient Egypt and Babylon. The most common procedure,
called couching, involved pressing 
a sharp instrument into the eye to loosen and push 
the clouded lens out of the way. Although this could increase 
the amount of light entering the eye, the lack of a lens would leave 
the patient's vision out of focus. Despite its low success rate,
and high risk of infection or injury, couching is still performed 
in some parts of the world. Later procedures would also focus
on removing the cloudy lens, for example, by making an opening
in the cornea to pull out the lens along with the membrane capsule 
surrounding it. While the invention of eyeglasses
allowed for some restoration of focus, they had to be extremely thick to help. Furthermore, such techniques
still caused complications, like damaging the retina, or leaving the eye 
with uncomfortable stitches. But in the 20th century, 
something unexpected happened. Eye surgeon Sir Harold Ridley was treating
World War II casualties when he noticed that acrylic plastic from
a shattered aircraft cockpit had become lodged in a pilot's eyes
without triggering an adverse reaction. This led him to propose surgically
implanting artificial lenses into the eye to replace cataracts. And despite initial resistance, the method became standard practice
by the 1980s. Since Ridley's discovery, the intraocular lens 
has undergone several improvements. Modern lenses can fit 
into the membrane capsule that the cataract is extracted from, leaving more of 
the eye's natural anatomy intact. And the ability to fine-tune 
the lens curvature allows the surgery to restore 
a patient's normal vision without the need for glasses. Of course, surgical techniques 
have also progressed. Microscopic procedures use 
small instruments or lasers to make precise incisions of one 
or two millimeters in the cornea, while an ultrasound probe breaks up
and removes the cataracted lens with minimal trauma to the eye. Low-tech versions of this operation have
made the surgery quick and inexpensive, helping it spread 
across the developing world. Places like Aravind Eye Hospital in India have pioneered high-volume, 
low-cost cataract surgery for as little as six dollars. Why then, with all these advances, are there still so many 
blind people in the world? The main issue is access to health care, with poor infrastructure 
and a shortage of doctors being a major barrier in many regions. But this is not the only problem. In many rural areas with poor education, blindness is often accepted 
as an inevitable part of aging, for which someone 
might not think to seek treatment. This is why information is crucial. Increased community awareness programs
and the spread of mobile phones mean that many of those who might have remained blind for
the rest of their lives due to cataracts are now reachable. And for them, 
a brighter future is in sight.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Modern day treatment of cataracts involves:
Options: A. Eye drops, B. Tablets, C. Eye surgery, D. Injections
Correct Option: C

The observation of acrylic plastic from a shattered aircraft cockpit in a pilot's eyes, C. The discovery of a new medication for cataracts, D. The development of microscopic procedures Correct Option: B

It has reduced the availability of intraocular lenses, D. It has had no impact on access to cataract surgery Correct Option: B
Question 8: If a 75-year-old patient is diagnosed with cataracts, what would be the most suitable treatment option? Options: A. Couching, B. Eyeglasses, C. Surgically implanting an intraocular lens, D. Medication Correct Option: C
Question 9: Compare the outcomes of cataract surgery using microscopic procedures versus earlier techniques. What are the main differences? Options: A. Microscopic procedures have a higher risk of infection and require thicker eyeglasses., B. Microscopic procedures have a lower success rate and cause more trauma to the eye., C. Microscopic procedures have a higher success rate, cause minimal trauma to the eye, and do not require eyeglasses., D. Microscopic procedures have the same outcomes as earlier techniques. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Evaluate the impact of community awareness programs on reducing the number of people blind due to cataracts. What is the likely outcome of such programs? Options: A. They will have no impact on reducing blindness due to cataracts., B. They will increase the number of people seeking treatment, but not reduce blindness., C. They will reduce the number of people blind due to cataracts by increasing awareness and access to treatment., D. They will only be effective in urban areas. Correct Option: C

Couching, B. Eyeglasses, C. Surgically implanting an intraocular lens, D. Medication Correct Option: C.

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: Describe the process of photosynthesis in plants. What is the primary byproduct of this process? Options: A. Oxygen and glucose, B. Carbon dioxide and water, C. Chlorophyll and sunlight, D. ATP and NADPH Correct Option: A
Question 3: A company is developing a new sustainable energy source using solar panels. What would be the most suitable location for installing these panels to maximize energy production? Options: A. Near the equator, B. In a densely forested area, C. On a north-facing slope, D. In a region with frequent cloud cover Correct Option: A
Question 4: Compare and contrast prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. What is the primary difference between these two types of cells? Options: A. Presence of a cell wall, B. Number of chromosomes, C. Presence of membrane-bound organelles, D. Cell size Correct Option: C
Question 5: Design an experiment to test the effect of pH on plant growth. What would be the independent variable in this experiment? Options: A. Light intensity, B. Water temperature, C. Soil pH, D. Fertilizer concentration Correct Option: C

Improved disease resistance, C. Unintended effects on non-target species, D. Reduced pesticide use Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the scientific term for the "building blocks of life"? Options: A. Cells, B. Molecules, C. Tissues, D. Organisms Correct Option: A
Question 8: Explain the concept of natural selection. What is the driving force behind this process? Options: A. Genetic drift, B. Mutation, C. Gene flow, D. Environmental pressures Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think back to a really vivid memory. Got it? Okay, now try to remember what 
you had for lunch three weeks ago. That second memory 
probably isn't as strong, but why not? Why do we remember some things,
and not others? And why do memories eventually fade? Let's look at how memories form
in the first place. When you experience something,
like dialing a phone number, the experience is converted 
into a pulse of electrical energy that zips along a network of neurons. Information first lands 
in short term memory, where it's available 
from anywhere from a few seconds to a couple of minutes. It's then transferred to long-term memory
through areas such as the hippocampus, and finally to several storage regions
across the brain. Neurons throughout the brain
communicate at dedicated sites called synapses using specialized neurotransmitters. If two neurons communicate repeatedly,
a remarkable thing happens: the efficiency of communication 
between them increases. This process, 
called long term potentiation, is considered to be a mechanism
by which memories are stored long-term, but how do some memories get lost? Age is one factor. As we get older, 
synapses begin to falter and weaken, affecting how easily 
we can retrieve memories. Scientists have several theories about
what's behind this deterioration, from actual brain shrinkage, the hippocampus 
loses 5% of its neurons every decade for a total loss of 20% by the time 
you're 80 years old to the drop in the production 
of neurotransmitters, like acetylcholine,
which is vital to learning and memory. These changes seem to affect how people
retrieve stored information. Age also affects 
our memory-making abilities. Memories are encoded most strongly
when we're paying attention, when we're deeply engaged,
and when information is meaningful to us. Mental and physical health problems,
which tend to increase as we age, interfere with our ability 
to pay attention, and thus act as memory thieves. Another leading cause of memory problems
is chronic stress. When we're constantly overloaded with work
and personal responsibilites, our bodies are on hyperalert. This response has evolved from
the physiological mechanism designed to make sure 
we can survive in a crisis. Stress chemicals help mobilize energy
and increase alertness. However, with chronic stress our bodies
become flooded with these chemicals, resulting in a loss of brain cells
and an inability to form new ones, which affects our ability 
to retain new information. Depression is another culprit. People who are depressed are 40%
more likely to develop memory problems. Low levels of serotonin, a neurotransmitter connected to arousal, may make depressed individuals 
less attentive to new information. Dwelling on sad events in the past,
another symptom of depression, makes it difficult to pay 
attention to the present, affecting the ability to store
short-term memories. Isolation, which is tied to depression,
is another memory thief. A study by the Harvard School 
of Public Health found that older people 
with high levels of social integration had a slower rate of memory decline
over a six-year period. The exact reason remains unclear, but experts suspect that social interaction 
gives our brain a mental workout. Just like muscle strength, we have to use our brain
or risk losing it. But don't despair. There are several steps you can take to aid your brain 
in preserving your memories. Make sure you keep physically active. Increased blood flow 
to the brain is helpful. And eat well. Your brain needs all the right nutrients
to keep functioning correctly. And finally, give your brain a workout. Exposing your brain to challenges,
like learning a new language, is one of the best defenses for keeping
your memories intact.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Long term potentiation is a mechanism by which:
Options: A. Memories are lost, B. Memories are stored, C. Memories are formed
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What happens to the efficiency of communication between two neurons when they communicate repeatedly? Options: A. It decreases, B. It remains the same, C. It increases, D. It becomes unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 2: Describe the process by which memories are stored long-term. Options: A. Through the conversion of experiences into electrical energy, B. Through the transfer of information from short-term to long-term memory, C. Through the process of long-term potentiation, where the efficiency of communication between neurons increases, D. Through the retrieval of stored information Correct Option: C
Question 3: A 60-year-old person is having trouble remembering recent events. What could be a possible reason for this? Options: A. The person's brain has shrunk by 20%, B. The person's hippocampus has lost 10% of its neurons, C. The person's neurotransmitter production has decreased, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 4: Analyze the relationship between chronic stress and memory problems. How do stress chemicals affect the brain? Options: A. They increase the production of neurotransmitters, B. They mobilize energy and increase alertness, but can lead to a loss of brain cells and inability to form new ones, C. They have no effect on the brain, D. They improve memory-making abilities Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the name of the neurotransmitter connected to arousal, which may be low in individuals with depression? Options: A. Acetylcholine, B. Serotonin, C. Dopamine, D. Norepinephrine Correct Option: B
Question 6: Design a plan to aid your brain in preserving memories. What three steps can you take? Options: A. Exercise regularly, eat a balanced diet, and get enough sleep, B. Keep physically active, eat well, and give your brain a workout, C. Reduce stress, increase social interaction, and take memory-enhancing supplements, D. None of the above Correct Option: B
Question 7: Evaluate the statement: "Social interaction gives our brain a mental workout." Do you agree or disagree? Options: A. Agree, because social interaction has been shown to slow down memory decline, B. Disagree, because social interaction has no effect on the brain, C. Agree, because social interaction increases stress levels, D. Disagree, because social interaction is not necessary for brain health Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the name of the process by which the brain converts experiences into electrical energy? Options: A. Long-term potentiation, B. Synaptic transmission, C. Neurotransmission, D. None of the above (the transcript does not mention a specific name for this process) Correct Option: D
Question 9: Compare and contrast the effects of age on memory-making abilities versus memory retrieval. How do these effects differ? Options: A. Age affects memory-making abilities more than memory retrieval, B. Age affects memory retrieval more than memory-making abilities, C. Age affects both memory-making abilities and memory retrieval equally, D. Age has no effect on either memory-making abilities or memory retrieval Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the name of the part of the brain responsible for transferring information from short-term to long-term memory? Options: A. Hippocampus, B. Cerebral cortex, C. Amygdala, D. Brainstem Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the process by which memories are stored long-term. The correct option, C, specifically mentions long-term potentiation as the mechanism by which memories are stored, which aligns with the correct option in the ground truth MCQ. 

While Question 1 also mentions long-term potentiation, it focuses more on the effect of repeated communication between neurons rather than the process of memory storage itself. Therefore, Question 2 is a better match for the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think back to a really vivid memory. Got it? Okay, now try to remember what 
you had for lunch three weeks ago. That second memory 
probably isn't as strong, but why not? Why do we remember some things,
and not others? And why do memories eventually fade? Let's look at how memories form
in the first place. When you experience something,
like dialing a phone number, the experience is converted 
into a pulse of electrical energy that zips along a network of neurons. Information first lands 
in short term memory, where it's available 
from anywhere from a few seconds to a couple of minutes. It's then transferred to long-term memory
through areas such as the hippocampus, and finally to several storage regions
across the brain. Neurons throughout the brain
communicate at dedicated sites called synapses using specialized neurotransmitters. If two neurons communicate repeatedly,
a remarkable thing happens: the efficiency of communication 
between them increases. This process, 
called long term potentiation, is considered to be a mechanism
by which memories are stored long-term, but how do some memories get lost? Age is one factor. As we get older, 
synapses begin to falter and weaken, affecting how easily 
we can retrieve memories. Scientists have several theories about
what's behind this deterioration, from actual brain shrinkage, the hippocampus 
loses 5% of its neurons every decade for a total loss of 20% by the time 
you're 80 years old to the drop in the production 
of neurotransmitters, like acetylcholine,
which is vital to learning and memory. These changes seem to affect how people
retrieve stored information. Age also affects 
our memory-making abilities. Memories are encoded most strongly
when we're paying attention, when we're deeply engaged,
and when information is meaningful to us. Mental and physical health problems,
which tend to increase as we age, interfere with our ability 
to pay attention, and thus act as memory thieves. Another leading cause of memory problems
is chronic stress. When we're constantly overloaded with work
and personal responsibilites, our bodies are on hyperalert. This response has evolved from
the physiological mechanism designed to make sure 
we can survive in a crisis. Stress chemicals help mobilize energy
and increase alertness. However, with chronic stress our bodies
become flooded with these chemicals, resulting in a loss of brain cells
and an inability to form new ones, which affects our ability 
to retain new information. Depression is another culprit. People who are depressed are 40%
more likely to develop memory problems. Low levels of serotonin, a neurotransmitter connected to arousal, may make depressed individuals 
less attentive to new information. Dwelling on sad events in the past,
another symptom of depression, makes it difficult to pay 
attention to the present, affecting the ability to store
short-term memories. Isolation, which is tied to depression,
is another memory thief. A study by the Harvard School 
of Public Health found that older people 
with high levels of social integration had a slower rate of memory decline
over a six-year period. The exact reason remains unclear, but experts suspect that social interaction 
gives our brain a mental workout. Just like muscle strength, we have to use our brain
or risk losing it. But don't despair. There are several steps you can take to aid your brain 
in preserving your memories. Make sure you keep physically active. Increased blood flow 
to the brain is helpful. And eat well. Your brain needs all the right nutrients
to keep functioning correctly. And finally, give your brain a workout. Exposing your brain to challenges,
like learning a new language, is one of the best defenses for keeping
your memories intact.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which two factors contribute to memory loss as we age:
Options: A. Brain shrinkage and extra neuronal connections, B. Brain growth and a drop in neurotransmitter production, C. Brain shrinkage and a drop in neurotransmitter production, D. Brain growth and extra neuronal connections
Correct Option: C

Through the transfer of information from short-term to long-term memory, C. Through the process of long-term potentiation, where the efficiency of communication between neurons increases, D. Through the retrieval of stored information Correct Option: C

Question 8: What is the name of the process by which the brain converts experiences into electrical energy? Options: A. Long-term potentiation, B. Synaptic transmission, C. Neurotransmission, D. None of the above (the transcript does not mention a specific name for this process) Correct Option: D
Question 9: Compare and contrast the effects of age on memory-making abilities versus memory retrieval. How do these effects differ? Options: A. Age affects memory-making abilities more than memory retrieval, B. Age affects memory retrieval more than memory-making abilities, C. Age affects both memory-making abilities and memory retrieval equally, D. Age has no effect on either memory-making abilities or memory retrieval Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
Think back to a really vivid memory. Got it? Okay, now try to remember what 
you had for lunch three weeks ago. That second memory 
probably isn't as strong, but why not? Why do we remember some things,
and not others? And why do memories eventually fade? Let's look at how memories form
in the first place. When you experience something,
like dialing a phone number, the experience is converted 
into a pulse of electrical energy that zips along a network of neurons. Information first lands 
in short term memory, where it's available 
from anywhere from a few seconds to a couple of minutes. It's then transferred to long-term memory
through areas such as the hippocampus, and finally to several storage regions
across the brain. Neurons throughout the brain
communicate at dedicated sites called synapses using specialized neurotransmitters. If two neurons communicate repeatedly,
a remarkable thing happens: the efficiency of communication 
between them increases. This process, 
called long term potentiation, is considered to be a mechanism
by which memories are stored long-term, but how do some memories get lost? Age is one factor. As we get older, 
synapses begin to falter and weaken, affecting how easily 
we can retrieve memories. Scientists have several theories about
what's behind this deterioration, from actual brain shrinkage, the hippocampus 
loses 5% of its neurons every decade for a total loss of 20% by the time 
you're 80 years old to the drop in the production 
of neurotransmitters, like acetylcholine,
which is vital to learning and memory. These changes seem to affect how people
retrieve stored information. Age also affects 
our memory-making abilities. Memories are encoded most strongly
when we're paying attention, when we're deeply engaged,
and when information is meaningful to us. Mental and physical health problems,
which tend to increase as we age, interfere with our ability 
to pay attention, and thus act as memory thieves. Another leading cause of memory problems
is chronic stress. When we're constantly overloaded with work
and personal responsibilites, our bodies are on hyperalert. This response has evolved from
the physiological mechanism designed to make sure 
we can survive in a crisis. Stress chemicals help mobilize energy
and increase alertness. However, with chronic stress our bodies
become flooded with these chemicals, resulting in a loss of brain cells
and an inability to form new ones, which affects our ability 
to retain new information. Depression is another culprit. People who are depressed are 40%
more likely to develop memory problems. Low levels of serotonin, a neurotransmitter connected to arousal, may make depressed individuals 
less attentive to new information. Dwelling on sad events in the past,
another symptom of depression, makes it difficult to pay 
attention to the present, affecting the ability to store
short-term memories. Isolation, which is tied to depression,
is another memory thief. A study by the Harvard School 
of Public Health found that older people 
with high levels of social integration had a slower rate of memory decline
over a six-year period. The exact reason remains unclear, but experts suspect that social interaction 
gives our brain a mental workout. Just like muscle strength, we have to use our brain
or risk losing it. But don't despair. There are several steps you can take to aid your brain 
in preserving your memories. Make sure you keep physically active. Increased blood flow 
to the brain is helpful. And eat well. Your brain needs all the right nutrients
to keep functioning correctly. And finally, give your brain a workout. Exposing your brain to challenges,
like learning a new language, is one of the best defenses for keeping
your memories intact.

Correct Option: C
